raw_text:
Home loan approvals rising again
 
 The number of mortgages approved in the UK has risen for the first time since May last year, according to lending figures from the Bank of England.
 
 New loans in December rose to 83,000, slightly higher than November's nine-year low of 77,000. Mortgage lending rose by £7.1bn in December, up from a £6.4bn rise in November. The figures contradict a survey from the British Bankers' Association, which said approvals were at a five-year low.
 
 Analysts say the figures show the market may be stabilising but still point to further house price softness. "The modest rise in mortgage approvals and lending in December reinforces the impression that the housing market is currently slowing steadily rather than sharply," said Global Insight analyst Howard Archer, commenting on the BoE's figures. The BBA believes that the property market is continuing to cool down. Changes to mortgage regulation may have artificially depressed figures in November, thus flattering the December figures, analysts said. In October last year, new rules came into force, which meant some lenders were forced to withdraw mortgage products temporarily in November and defer some lending until they had made sure they had complied with the rules properly. Separately, the Bank of England said that consumer credit rose by £1.5bn in December, more than the £1.4bn expected and above the £1.4bn reported in the previous month.
llama3.2:1b: Mortgage lending in the UK has risen to 83,000 in December, up from a November low of 77,000.
The Bank of England attributes this rise to stabilizing market conditions rather than a sharp increase, citing potential further house price softening.
llama3.2:3b: UK mortgage approvals rose for the first time since May last year to 83,000 in December, with a £7.1bn increase in lending.
The rise contradicts a survey that said approvals were at a five-year low and analysts attribute this to potential changes in mortgage regulation causing an artificially low November figure.

However, this increase contradicts a British Bankers' Association survey indicating a five-year low in approvals.
Analysts suggest a stabilizing market but acknowledge continued house price softness.
Changes to mortgage regulation may have inflated December figures.
Consumer credit also rose significantly in December.

Analysts interpret this as steady housing market stabilization but also note potential softening of house prices.
Consumer credit rose by £1.5bn in December, up from October regulations.

Mortgage lending increased by £7.1bn in December compared to £6.4bn in November.
While this contradicts a five-year low reported by the British Bankers' Association, analysts suggest the market is stabilizing but still showing signs of house price softness.
Analysts attribute some of the rise in December to temporary withdrawal of mortgage products due to new regulations implemented in October.
Consumer credit also rose by £1.5bn in December, exceeding expectations and up from November's reported amount.
